uh Arthur Grossman and I'm a Staff
scientist at the Carnegie Institution
for Science which is on the Stanford
campus I went to Indiana University
where I got a
PhD um and then I went back to New York
to Rockefeller University where I worked
on um the biogenesis of chloroplast
plasts in um land plants and in 1982 I
accepted a position at Carnegie so I've
been here for over 30 years
now so to me algae are an untapped
source of food and products that can be
used very productively by humans but
they're also one of the most you know
they're incredibly diverse they cover
the planet and we know very little
really about them we know little about
their we're learning more about their
diversity but we don't know the
mechanisms by which the the molecular
and the biological mechanisms that that
they that they use to deal with the
changing environment and to deal with
their natural environment the products
that we get out of algae are just
minimal right now and I think some of
the best oils for example are made um by
algae and they could be used very very
beneficially as food oils I also think
that they will be a source they can be
used as a source of fuel in the future
